s.text: Instead of writing this book--and book-writing is surely a job for sissies--he should have gone out and beat someone up or sold drugs.
Instead of writing this book--and book-writing is surely a job for sissies--he should have gone out and beat someone up or sold drugs.
Instead of writing this book--and book-writing is surely a job for sissies--he should have gone out and beat someone up or sold drugs.
Jews You Can Use
He does this by striking a tough guy pose throughout, a pose that fails to hide his sense of physical inadequacy, which he blames on his Jewishness:
He does this by striking a tough guy pose throughout, a pose that fails to hide his sense of physical inadequacy, which he blames on his Jewishness:
"I once heard a comedian refer jokingly to the Jewish Mafia," he writes.
By the time I hit 16, my understanding of Jewish gangsters had become substantially more nuanced.
Sometimes, when I see this comedian's bit rerun on cable, I imagine Pep Strauss"--a hit man in the hit-man organization called Murder Inc.--"entering stage left and cutting him belly to chin."
Great nicknames and fists aside, I began to recognize these Jewish gangsters as fools and thugs who preyed on their own communities, robbed the Jewish poor, and murdered their own people.
Great nicknames and fists aside, I began to recognize these Jewish gangsters as fools and thugs who preyed on their own communities, robbed the Jewish poor, and murdered their own people.
Great nicknames and fists aside, I began to recognize these Jewish gangsters as fools and thugs who preyed on their own communities, robbed the Jewish poor, and murdered their own people.
Great nicknames and fists aside, I began to recognize these Jewish gangsters as fools and thugs who preyed on their own communities, robbed the Jewish poor, and murdered their own people.
Jews, he writes, "have pushed aside the image of the gangster: Forget.
Forget when you were bullies.
Jews, he writes, "have pushed aside the image of the gangster: Forget.
Forget when you were bullies.
the blood drains from their faces."

This reaction is easy to understand: I was, at the time, facing the oppression of anti-Semitic schoolyard thugs, and in my revenge-fantasies, Bugsy Siegel and Gurrah Shapiro were lining up on my side, blackjacks in hand.

When Cohen is not "imagining" history, he rewrites other people's research, sometimes mangling quotes during his copying, as he did when he took a quote from a 1951 book, Murder, Inc.: The Story of "the Syndicate ," by , also about Jewish gangsters.
When I tell old Jews about this book, ...
